node.title: One year after FDA authorized Pfizer's COVID vaccine, cases are on the rise
node.description: Saturday marks one year since the Food and Drug Administration authorized Pfizer's COVID-19​ vaccine.

node.title: Is it safe to attend the company holiday party this year?
node.description: After COViD-19 shut down last year's festivities, in-person company gatherings are making a comeback.

node.title: Chris Wallace leaving Fox News for CNN
node.description: "After 18 years, this is my final 'Fox News Sunday,'" Wallace said.

node.title: Peloton responds to "And Just Like That" scene with Mr. Big himself
node.description: "And just like that...he's alive."

node.title: Has Anyone Died From Omicron COVID variant? First Death Reported in U.K.
node.description: Announcing the death, U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson said: "The idea that this is somehow a milder version of the virus, I think that's something we need to set on one side and just recognise the sheer pace at which it accelerates through the population."

node.title: Supermassive Black Hole at Center of Our Galaxy Hiccups As It Feeds
node.description: New research from the Hubble Space Telescope suggests that our galaxy's central black hole Sagittarius A* belches out jets of material as it swallows surrounding gas clouds.

node.title: Bizarre and Rarely Seen Fish with Translucent Head and Glowing Eyes Filmed off California
node.description: The barreleye fish has only been filmed by the Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute nine times in over 5,600 dives.

node.title: 'Her life was ended for her': Inquest into disappearance of mother of six begins
node.description: A coronial inquest into the disappearance and likely death of Devonport mother Darlene Geertsema, who was last seen in 1978, begins in Launceston.

node.title: Federal student loan payments are set to restart soon
node.description: Federal student loan payments paused during the pandemic are set to start back up for millions of borrowers beginning in February.

node.title: Israeli Leader Meets Emirati Crown Prince in Abu Dhabi
node.description: Prime Minister Naftali Bennett met Prince Mohammed bin Zayed, the de facto leader of the United Arab Emirates, on a historic official trip to the Gulf state.

node.title: YouTubers help solve cold cases — and get billions of views
node.description: Internet sleuthing has had a mixed impact, with both high-profile misfires and critical contributions, experts say.

node.title: Six-Year-Old Dies of Cancer After Family Spots Unusual Changes in Her Face
node.description: Acacia Surridge-Hill was eventually diagnosed with a diffuse midline glioma—a rare and aggressive form of cancer.

node.title: Putin says USSR collapse forced him to work as taxi driver
node.description: The Russian leader, who was a KGB agent when the Soviet Union crumbled, said "it's not pleasant to talk about it, but unfortunately, that was the case."

node.title: Rhino Poachers Massacre Dozens Including Pregnant Female in 'Horrific Scene'
node.description: Four suspects have been arrested for the killings of four of the 22 rhinos butchered in the last week.

node.title: Coast Guard Suspends Search for Woman Who Fell Overboard on Carnival Cruise
node.description: The woman went overboard from the balcony of her stateroom aboard the Carnival cruise ship near Ensenada, Mexico.

node.title: Heirloom Lost in Kentucky Tornado Found on Windshield 130 Miles Away, Reunited With Family
node.description: Indiana resident Katie Posten took to social media to find the family photo's owner, after discovering it on her car, amazingly with no other debris around.

node.title: Glimmer of relief amid deadly tornadoes' devastation
node.description: Ninety feared dead in a Kentucky candle factory actually survived, the company says. But the confirmed death toll of 25 in several Midwestern and Southern states seems certain to rise.

node.title: Israeli Leader Travels to U.A.E., Showcasing Deepening Ties
node.description: Prime Minister Naftali Bennett traveled to Abu Dhabi on Sunday, the first such visit by an Israeli leader, with plans to meet with the Emirati prince.

node.title: America’s Anti-Democratic Movement
node.description: It’s making progress.

node.title: 'They Were Spying On Us': Amazon, Walmart, Use Surveillance Technology to Bust Unions
node.description: An estimated 60 percent of large employers use workplace monitoring tools, some of which can be used to chill organizing.

node.title: It May Not Feel Like It Right Now, but There Is a World of Good We Can Do
node.description: A few worthies from Times Opinion’s giving guide and a few ... unworthies.

node.title: We’ve Failed Our Planet. This Is an SOS.
node.description: The climate crisis is now.

node.title: When Is the UEFA Champions League Round of 16 Draw?
node.description: Chelsea, Liverpool, Real Madrid, Bayern Munich and the rest of the teams still in the UEFA Champions League will find out who their next opponent is today.

node.title: China Offers U.S. Humanitarian Assistance Following Kentucky Tornado Disaster
node.description: "We expressed our condolences and willingness to provide emergency humanitarian help to the affected people according to the needs of the U.S. side."

node.title: Can We Have a Meaningful Life in a Virtual World?
node.description: “Am I dipping into the spiritual realm and the infinite game of life? Damn right I am.”

node.title: Shopping for Champagne Glasses
node.description: It’s almost time to raise a glass to the new year. What kind of glass should it be?

node.title: In Nadifa Mohamed’s Latest, a Man Hangs for a Murder He Didn’t Commit
node.description: A Booker Prize finalist, “The Fortune Men” fictionalizes the story of the Somali seaman who became the last man to be hanged by the state in Cardiff, Wales, in 1952.

node.title: With Paige Bueckers Injured, UConn Faces a Tough Few Months
node.description: The No. 3 Huskies will be without the best player in women’s college basketball for up to eight weeks and, with a win and a loss in her absence, it’s difficult to say yet how they will fare.

node.title: Introducing Times Opinion’s Holiday Giving Guide
node.description: There are many ways to give back this season.

node.title: Buy an Earth Suit, Shoot Sulfur into the Atmosphere (And Other Contingency Plans for a Warming Earth)
node.description: The novelist Neal Stephenson offers some tips for how you can survive the climate crisis.
